awd_titl_txt: SG: A revised taxonomy of the palm genus Iguanura
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to document the biodiversity of a group of Asian palms and update its classification. This project will improve understanding of the geographic distribution and abundance of these species of palms, enabling informed decisions about conservation priorities. Additionally, the results of the project will be combined with results from many other, similar studies on palms and serve to further the understanding of the biology of the economically important palm family. All the resulting data from the project will be freely available to any interested party, and the final publication will be in open access format. This project will also serve as a model for other studies of species delimitation by employing a rigorous scientific methodology to the systematic study of palms. 

Iguanura is the name given to a group of small, stilt-rooted, understory palms with undivided or pinnate leaves, leaflets with jagged margins, and unusually variable fruits. The genus occurs in tropical rainforests in Myanmar, Peninsular Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, and Borneo. Approximately 34 species have been recognized, including a recently described species that was discovered over 1,800 km north of the nearest known locality in Peninsular Thailand, emphasizing how the genus has been poorly understood. The most recent systematic study of the whole genus was carried out over 45 years ago and relied entirely on the relatively few herbarium specimens existing at that time. A second important study, published over 15 years ago, dealt only with species from Peninsular Malaysia and relied on extensive field work and collecting. Neither of these studies employed an explicit species delimitation methodology. The present study of Iguanura will employ an explicit, repeatable methodology based on a clearly stated species concept. It will test previously published species as hypotheses based on the quantitative analysis of data, using all relevant specimens in the larger herbaria in the US, Europe, and Asia. This analysis, along with extensive study of herbarium specimens, will form the basis for a modern taxonomic revision of the genus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Number: 2039979
Project Title: SG: A revised taxonomy of the palm genus Iguanura
PI: Andrew Henderson
Awardee: New York Botanical Garden

 

The palm genus Iguanura is widely distributed in the understory of tropical forests in Peninsular Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, and Borneo, with an outlier in northern Myanmar. These palms are small in size, usually under 2 m tall, and are easily recognized by their stilt roots, jagged leaf apices, and unusual fruits. The genus was last studied in its entirety almost 50 years ago, and was consequently poorly known. The purpose of this project was to produce a modern revision of the genus based on study of herbarium specimens from herbaria in the US, Europe, and Asia.

 

Specifically, this NSF grant supported visits to two herbaria in Europe (the Kew herbarium in the UK and the Florence herbarium in Italy) and three herbaria in Asia (the Forestry Research Institute herbarium in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the Singapore herbarium, and the Sarawak herbarium in Kuching, Malaysia). The Kew and Florence herbaria were visited in August-September 2022; the FRIM herbarium in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore herbarium were visited in September-October 2023; and the Sarawak herbarium in Kuching was visited in September 2024.

 

As a result of these visits, 446 specimens of Iguanura were examined and their data entered into a project database. These, together with 224 specimens studied in other herbaria, gives a total of 670 specimens. The data from all these specimens, comprising geographical coordinates for each specimen as well as quantitative and qualitative data, was added to the project database, and this formed the basis of the resulting revision.

 

The final revision was submitted to the botanical journal Phytotaxa in December 2024 and is currently being reviewed. The submitted manuscript comprised 91 printed pages, 15 figures, and nine plates. The manuscript contained introductory discussions of morphology, illustrated by figures of relevant features; full nomenclature; full descriptions of each species based on the database; and a discussion of the distribution and habitat of each species with distribution maps based on the database. This revision recognized 30 species of Iguanura, nine of them described as new species. The project database will be freely available on both the New York Botanical Garden’s website and on Zenodo (an online repository of scientific data).

 


Last Modified: 03/08/2025
Modified by: Andrew J Henderson

Project Outcomes Report
 
 


Award Number: 2039979
 Project Title: SG: A revised taxonomy of the palm genus Iguanura
 PI: Andrew Henderson
 Awardee: New York Botanical Garden





The palm genus Iguanura is widely distributed in the understory of tropical forests in Peninsular Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, and Borneo, with an outlier in northern Myanmar. These palms are small in size, usually under 2 m tall, and are easily recognized by their stilt roots, jagged leaf apices, and unusual fruits. The genus was last studied in its entirety almost 50 years ago, and was consequently poorly known. The purpose of this project was to produce a modern revision of the genus based on study of herbarium specimens from herbaria in the US, Europe, and Asia.





Specifically, this NSF grant supported visits to two herbaria in Europe (the Kew herbarium in the UK and the Florence herbarium in Italy) and three herbaria in Asia (the Forestry Research Institute herbarium in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the Singapore herbarium, and the Sarawak herbarium in Kuching, Malaysia). The Kew and Florence herbaria were visited in August-September 2022; the FRIM herbarium in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore herbarium were visited in September-October 2023; and the Sarawak herbarium in Kuching was visited in September 2024.





As a result of these visits, 446 specimens of Iguanura were examined and their data entered into a project database. These, together with 224 specimens studied in other herbaria, gives a total of 670 specimens. The data from all these specimens, comprising geographical coordinates for each specimen as well as quantitative and qualitative data, was added to the project database, and this formed the basis of the resulting revision.





The final revision was submitted to the botanical journal Phytotaxa in December 2024 and is currently being reviewed. The submitted manuscript comprised 91 printed pages, 15 figures, and nine plates. The manuscript contained introductory discussions of morphology, illustrated by figures of relevant features; full nomenclature; full descriptions of each species based on the database; and a discussion of the distribution and habitat of each species with distribution maps based on the database. This revision recognized 30 species of Iguanura, nine of them described as new species. The project database will be freely available on both the New York Botanical Gardens website and on Zenodo (an online repository of scientific data).
